original_title: University Teachers Vow to Continue Tax Protest Despite Allowance Boost
original_body_lines: COLOMBO (News 1st); The Federation of University Teachers' Associations (FUTA) has resolved to continue its campaign against what it deems an unfair tax policy.
This decision was reached at the association's Executive Committee meeting held last night.

Over the past year, the  Federation of University Teachers' Associations and the Government Medical Officers' Association, partnering with a coalition of 40 other professional organizations under the Professionals Trade Union Collective, launched a campaign to demand the reduction of unfairly levied personal income tax, arguing that its structure placed an unfair burden on professionals.

They argued that the sharp rise in personal income tax from 6% to 36% for incomes exceeding 100,000 rupees was driving a worrying trend of professional emigration and jeopardizing Sri Lanka's skilled workforce.
In a cabinet meeting, President Ranil Wickremesinghe approved a 25% increase in the allowance for university professors, effective January.
Notably, University lecturers were very active in the recent tax protests alongside medical professionals.
The government has implemented measures granting special privileges to two key groups within the Professionals Trade Union Collective.
The Government Medical Officers' Association and the Federation of University Teachers' Associations welcomed the allowance increase as a positive step towards addressing their concerns.
